title: 106_hr2309
content: The Act may be cited as the "Independent Medical Review Act of 1999" and includes special rules for group health plans. Section 503 of ERISA is amended to include special rules for group health plans, such as notification of appeal rights to utilization review agents and independent review organizations. The amendment to Section 503 of ERISA includes rules for group health plans regarding notification of appeal rights to utilization review agents and independent review organizations, including procedures for appealing adverse determinations and obtaining immediate review for life-threatening conditions. The independent review organization must conduct a fair, de novo determination of medical necessity without being bound by the plan's definition. The amendment to Section 503 of ERISA allows participants to appeal adverse benefit determinations to utilization review agents. The procedures for appeals must be reasonable and allow for oral or written appeals. The utilization review agent must respond within 5 working days. The amendment to Section 503 of ERISA allows participants to appeal adverse benefit determinations to utilization review agents. The procedures for appeals must be reasonable and allow for oral or written appeals. The utilization review agent must acknowledge receipt of the appeal within 5 working days and provide a list of required documents. If an oral appeal is made, a one-page appeal form will be sent to the appealing party. Appeal decisions will be made by a physician, with the option for the health care provider to provide written justification for a specialty provider if the appeal is denied. The health care provider must provide good cause in writing for a specialty review of denied cases, which must be completed within 15 working days. An expedited appeal procedure is required for emergency care denials, life-threatening conditions, and denied hospital stays, involving a review by a specialist who has not previously reviewed the case. The expedited appeal process for emergency care denials requires a specialist review within one working day of receiving all necessary information. The utilization review agent must issue a response letter explaining the resolution of the appeal to the patient or their healthcare provider. The resolution of an appeal must be explained in a letter to the patient or healthcare provider, detailing medical reasons and clinical basis. Notification of the appeal determination must be provided within 30 days. If an appeal is denied, independent review by an organization is allowed. The independent review process allows a participant to seek review of an adverse determination from an independent review organization. It ensures timely response, confidentiality of medical records, independence of healthcare providers, and timely notice to the participant. The independent review process allows participants to seek review of adverse determinations from an independent organization, ensuring timely response and confidentiality of medical records. Utilization review agents must provide relevant medical records to the independent review organization within 3 business days of a review request. The independent review organization requires relevant medical records, documents used in the determination, written notification of denial basis, information submitted for appeal, and a list of physicians involved. The independent review organization needs medical records and a list of physicians involved for the appeal process, with timelines for making determinations. The independent review organization must make determinations within specific timelines for appeals, including life-threatening conditions. The independent review organization must make determinations within specific timelines for appeals, including life-threatening conditions. To be treated as an independent review organization, an organization must be certified by the Secretary. An organization seeking certification must submit an annual application with required information. The application to be submitted to the Secretary must include details such as the names of stockholders owning more than 5%, affiliated organizations, bond holders exceeding $100,000, and biographical information of directors, officers, and executives. The application must include the names and biographical sketches of directors, officers, and executives, along with any relationships they have with entities such as health insurance providers, health maintenance organizations, and healthcare providers. The application for independent review must include details such as the applicant's anticipated revenue sources, the expertise of healthcare professionals involved in review determinations, and the procedures used by the independent review organization. The independent review organization's determinations are final and binding on the plan, subject to possible vacation or modification by a court. An independence requirement is also mandated for the independent review process. An independent review organization conducting a review under this section is not liable for damages arising from the determination made by the organization. The term 'adverse determination' refers to a determination that the health care services provided are not medically necessary. The utilization review agent determines if health care services are medically necessary. A health care provider is defined as an individual or entity delivering health care services in a State. Life-threatening condition is also defined. The term 'payor' refers to entities providing health insurance policies, preferred provider organizations, self-insurance plans, or entities offering health benefits. A life-threatening condition is defined as a medical condition where death or serious bodily injury is likely without interruption of the disease or condition. A utilization review agent conducts utilization review for employers, payors, or administrators. A working day is defined as a weekday excluding legal holidays.
